text: hello everyone I am Niharika and welcome
to a new lesson today we are going to
look at some etiquette for conferences
and meetings so do you dread meetings
well remember meetings and conferences
put you in front of the co-workers and
bosses with whom you don't work on
regular basis so the way you conduct
yourself in front of them would leave a
lasting impression so that's exactly
this lesson is going to help you with
some etiquette that you need to follow
when you are attending conferences and
meetings the first one that we have for
you is be on time now of course time is
precious so it's extremely important for
you to be on time and of course prepare
yourself ahead of time which means you
need to have a strong agenda for your
meeting definitely you do not want to
waste
others time so make sure you are
punctual
second etiquette that I have for you is
make introductions and acknowledge now
it is important for you when you enter a
room you need to acknowledge other
attendees
don't just walk into the room and have a
seat
that's arrogance so please do
acknowledge if you don't know people
introduce yourself and familiarize
yourself with all other people in the
room also try to put names on the faces
that you have met before and of course
do remember all other names that you are
newly introduced to the third one that I
have for you is do not keep your phone
out on the table I know it's very
difficult for everyone to live without
their phone calls or without their
emails or messages but wouldn't you like
to show the chairperson who's taking the
meeting that this meeting is the most
important thing for you right now
so please keep your phone inside or else
it would be a big distraction for
yourself and for the other attendees in
the room
the fourth ethicist is to speak up it's
important for you to be loud and clear
when you are putting forward to your
point especially women women are not
loud enough or they are really subtle
when they are trying to put a point
forward so this really doesn't sound
professional now speak up doesn't mean
that you interrupt someone someone is
speaking and then you just interrupt
them and give your point out hmm that's
also not professional so make sure that
you loud and clear and you take notes so
that you can speak up when it's the
right time the last one that we have for
you is do not save your questions for
the last now many people tend to ask
questions when people are ready to leave
which means when the meeting is about to
get over people try to add stuff or ask
a revelant questions which are
definitely not required so it's
important for you to ask right questions
at the right time and add correct
information at the right time this would
make you sound very professional this
brings me to the end of this lesson
make sure you follow these advocates for
meetings and conferences and trust me
your boss and co-workers would be highly
impressed I'll see you in your next
lesson till then you take care and have
a good day
